p: MOF have been of great interest due to the wide amount of applications, for instance, catalysis (Shen et al., 2016), magnetism (Tian et al., 2014), luminescence (Allendorf et al., 2009), gas detection (Drobek et al., 2016), water purification (Ma et al., 2017), gas storage (Li and Yang, 2007), adsorption properties (Kaur et al., 2019), and supercapacitors (Lee et al., 2009). The latter is another great advantage of MOF, since the structural flexibility vs. external stimuli (changes in temperature and pressure), that varies their porosity. For this reason, it is possible to promote their use as molecular sieves (Bux et al., 2010) and drug-releasing capsules (Orellana-Tavra et al., 2016), among other things. This versatility in their application is due to the properties such as the high specific surface area of >1,000 m2/g, a regular and adjustable pore texture, flexibility in surface chemistry, and high chemical and thermal stability (Xia, 2011).
